symbol.name: n_D
symbol.doc: Number of diffractograms. For example the number of energy-dispersive detectors or the number of azimuthal sections in an area detector.

symbol.name: c_Unit
symbol.doc: Converted diffractogram X units (could be the same as *x_Unit*).

symbol.name: n_sField
symbol.doc: number of values in applied stress field

symbol.name: nP
symbol.doc: number of scan points (only present in scanning measurements)

symbol.name: i
symbol.doc: number of detector pixels in the first (slowest) direction

symbol.name: j
symbol.doc: number of detector pixels in the second (faster) direction

definition.doc:
Application definition for stress and strain analysis of crystalline material defined by the `EASI-STRESS consortium <https://easi-stress.eu>`_.
When a crystal is loaded (applied or residual stress) its crystallographic parameters change.
Stress and strain analysis calculates deformation (strain) and the associated force (stress) from diffraction data.
This application definition essentially standardizes the result of diffraction pattern analysis from different types of diffraction experiments for the purpose of stress and strain analysis. The analysis is typically some form of diffraction peak indexing and fitting. The experiments are for example
- energy-dispersive X-ray powder diffraction - angular-dispersive X-ray powder diffraction - angular-dispersive neutron powder diffraction - time-of-flight (TOF) neutron powder diffraction.
In addition, the application definition guarantees that the information about instrumental setups, measurement conditions, and data analysis workflows are described. This ensures not only the reproducability and tracability of the measured data, but also the metadata. Since not all participating beamlines or instruments can provide an input to all the NeXus fields listed in this application definition, not all of them are "required".
However, when possible and technically feasible, the instrument using the NXstress application definition is expected to provide the type of information outlined below.
Sample and detector positions can be defined with :ref:`NXtransformations`. If you don't specify the direction of gravity and the direction of the beam then the standard NeXus Coordinate System is used.
It is highly recommended that when certain parameters or values are the same for all the measurements (acquistions) in the same file, they are stored only in one location and then linked in the other instances. For example, if during an acquisition all
instrumental parameters but one stay the same and only the sample table moves in one direction (e.g. Xtranslation), then all the static instrumental parameters should be saved just once (e.g. in just one NXentry or in a *Shared_Information group*) and their values linked to every *instrument group* under all the other acquisitions. The value for the variable that changes, Xtranslation in this example, is suggested to be saved only at every instrument group under each acquistion but not in the *Shared_Information group*.
It is not always necessary to link each field. In case all the fields with an entire group are the same, the entire group can be linked.

group.doc: The name of the *NXentry group(s)* can be freely chosen by the facility. The *NXentry group* can contain any form of data acquisition (e.g. a measurement point, multiple measurement points, a line scan, a mesh, all data points from one sample â€¦).

field.name: definition
field.doc: Official NeXus NXDL schema to which this file conforms

field.name: title
field.doc: Extended title for the entry.

field.name: experiment_identifier
field.doc: Unique identifier for the experiment as defined by the facility (e.g. DOI, proposal id, ...). At ILL, this could be, for example, ``exp_1-02-286``, ``exp_INDU-229``, or ``exp_INTER-569``.

field.name: experiment_description
field.doc: Brief summary of the experiment, including key objectives. At least one of the following information should be provided: * ``energy-dispersive X-ray powder diffraction`` * ``angular-dispersive X-ray powder diffraction`` * ``angular-dispersive neutron powder diffraction`` * ``time-of-flight (TOF) neutron powder diffraction``

field.name: start_time
field.doc: The starting time(s) of measurement(s) which can be provided in form of a list if multiple measurements are included in the same NXentry.

field.name: end_time
field.doc: The end time(s) of measurement(s) which can be provided in form of a list if multiple measurements are included in the same NXentry.

field.name: collection_identifier
field.doc: User or Data Acquisition defined identifier from which the content of this application definition is derived. This can be freely chosen by the user or the instrument scientist and could be, for example, ``05_DA_650_AX_B3P5``, ``SENB-14``, ``Quartz``,....

field.name: collection_description
field.doc: Brief summary of the collection, including grouping criteria. The information provided in this field can highlight, for example, the measurement setup or information about experimental conditions.

field.name: processing_type
field.doc: Describes the way strain :math:`\varepsilon` can be calculated from the :ref:`center </NXstress/ENTRY/peaks/center-field>` peak parameter.

item.doc: A description of the :math:`\mathrm{\sin}^{2}\psi` method can be found in the literature. Two examples are `Fitzpatrick et al. 2005 <http://eprintspublications.npl.co.uk/id/eprint/2391>`_ and `DIN ISO 15305:2009-01 <https://www.en-standard.eu/din-en-15305-non-destructive-testing-test-method-for-residual-stress-analysis-by-x-ray-diffraction/>`_.

field.name: measurement_direction
field.doc: Describes the specific measurement direction covered by the data in this file.

group.name: experiment_responsible
group.doc: Information about the person who performed the experiment.

field.name: role
field.doc: Role of user responsible for this entry. Suggested roes are, for example, ``local contact``, ``beamline_scientist``, ``post_doc``,â€¦

field.name: name
field.doc: Name of the diffractometer, instrument, or beamline used for the experiment. This could be, for example, *Strain Analyser for Large and Small scale engineering Applications*.

attribute.name: short_name
attribute.doc: Short name for the instrument, perhaps the acronym, which would be for the the example above ``SALSA``.

group.name: CALIBRATION
group.doc: This group contains information about the geometry and/or efficiency measurement(s).

field.name: calibration_type
field.doc: Describe the type of calibration.

field.name: file_name
field.doc: File name(s) and/or path(s) (within file(s)) containing data from the last calibration(s). This can be an array.

field.name: data
field.doc: Calibration file content.

field.name: type
field.doc: Mime content type of calibration *data* field e.g. text/plain, application/json,...

field.name: author
field.doc: Author or creator of the calibration.

field.name: date
field.doc: Date calibration was created/added

field.name: type
field.doc: Type of radiation source

field.name: probe
field.doc: Type of radiation probe

group.name: DETECTOR
group.doc: Zero or more of these groups describe the detectors used in the experiment.

field.name: description
field.doc: name/manufacturer/model/etc. information

field.name: type
field.doc: Description of type such as \ :sup:`3`\ He gas cylinder, \ :sup:`3`\ He PSD, scintillator, fission chamber, proportion counter, ion chamber, CCD, pixel, image plate, CMOS, â€¦

field.name: distance
field.doc:
This is the distance to the previous component in the instrument; most often the sample. The usage depends on the nature of the detector: Most often it is the distance of the detector assembly. But there are irregular detectors. In this case the distance must be specified for each detector pixel.
Note, it is recommended to use NXtransformations instead.

field.name: efficiency
field.doc: efficiency of the detector

field.name: wavelength
field.doc:
This field can be two things:
1. For a pixel detector it provides the nominal wavelength for which the detector has been calibrated.
2. For other detectors this field has to be seen together with the efficiency field above. For some detectors, the efficiency is wavelength dependent. Thus this field provides the wavelength axis for the efficiency field. In this use case, the efficiency and wavelength arrays must have the same dimensionality.

field.name: dead_time
field.doc: Detector dead time

field.name: count_time
field.doc: Elapsed actual counting time

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: The axis on which the detector position depends may be stored anywhere, but is normally stored in the *NXtransformations group* within the *NXdetector group*.

group.doc: This is the recommended location for detector goniometer and other related axes.

group.name: beam_intensity_profile
group.doc:
Defines the dimensions of the beam profile used for probing the sample which corresponds to or can be used to determine the instrumental gauge volume. A description of the subsequent fields can be found in the folowing figure. The term "primary" in the subsequent fields refers to the beam path between the sample and the source. The term "secondary" refers to the beam path between the sample and the detector(s).
.. figure:: stress/Beam_profile_sketch3.jpg :width: 70% :alt: Examples for the beam intensity profile.
Some examples for the beam intensity profile. The 1D description of the beam profile on the right can equally be applied for the horizontal and vertical direction for the primary and the secondary side.

field.name: beam_evaluation
field.doc: If the beam profile was measured, the filename(s) of the measurement can be specified here.

field.name: primary_vertical_type
field.doc: Defines the last device right in front of the sample used to shape the beam. This could be, for example, a :ref:`(radial) collimator <NXcollimator>` or a :ref:`slit <NXslit>`.

field.name: primary_vertical_source_width
field.doc: Defines the primary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the source in the vertical direction.

field.name: primary_vertical_sample_width
field.doc: Defines the primary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the sample in the vertical direction.

field.name: primary_vertical_distance
field.doc: Defines the distance between the center of the gauge volume and the beam shaping device.

field.name: primary_vertical_evaluation
field.doc: Describes how the beam intensity profile in the primary vertical direction was determined. Examples of valid entries are: ``measured``, ``theoretical``, ``estimated``, ...

field.name: primary_horizontal_type
field.doc: Defines the last device right in front of the sample used to shape the beam. This could be, for example, a :ref:`(radial) collimator <NXcollimator>` or a :ref:`slit <NXslit>`.

field.name: primary_horizontal_source_width
field.doc: Defines the primary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the source in the horizontal direction.

field.name: primary_horizontal_sample_width
field.doc: Defines the primary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the sample in the horizontal direction.

field.name: primary_horizontal_distance
field.doc: Defines the distance between the center of the gauge volume and the beam shaping device.

field.name: primary_horizontal_evaluation
field.doc: Describes how the beam intensity profile in the primary horizontal direction was determined. Examples of valid entries are: ``measured``, ``theoretical``, ``estimated``, ...

field.name: secondary_horizontal_type
field.doc: Defines the last device right in front of the sample used to shape the beam. This could be, for example, a :ref:`(radial) collimator <NXcollimator>` or a :ref:`slit <NXslit>`.

field.name: secondary_horizontal_detector_width
field.doc: Defines the secondary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the detector in the horizontal direction.

field.name: secondary_horizontal_sample_width
field.doc: Defines the secondary beam size intensity profile on the side closer to the sample in the horizontal direction.

field.name: secondary_horizontal_distance
field.doc: Defines the distance between the center of the gauge volume and the beam shaping device.

field.name: secondary_horizontal_evaluation
field.doc: Describes how the beam intensity profile in the secondary horizontal direction was determined. Examples of valid entries are: ``measured``, ``theoretical``, ``estimated``, ...

field.name: incident_energy
field.doc: Incident energy mostly useful for monochromatic beams.

field.name: incident_wavelength
field.doc: Incident wavelength mostly useful for monochromatic beams.

group.name: SAMPLE_DESCRIPTION
group.doc: This is the recommended location for describing parameters associated with the sample.

field.name: name
field.doc: Descriptive name of sample

field.name: chemical_formula
field.doc:
The chemical formula specified using CIF conventions. Abbreviated version of CIF standard:
* Only recognized element symbols may be used. * Each element symbol is followed by a 'count' number. A count of '1' may be omitted. * A space or parenthesis must separate each cluster of (element symbol + count). * Where a group of elements is enclosed in parentheses, the multiplier for the group must follow the closing parentheses. That is, all element and group multipliers are assumed to be printed as subscripted numbers. * Unless the elements are ordered in a manner that corresponds to their chemical structure, the order of the elements within any group or moiety depends on whether or not carbon is present. * If carbon is present, the order should be:
- C, then H, then the other elements in alphabetical order of their symbol. - If carbon is not present, the elements are listed purely in alphabetic order of their symbol.
* This is the *Hill* system used by Chemical Abstracts.

field.name: temperature
field.doc: Sample temperature. This could be a scanned variable

field.name: stress_field
field.doc: Applied external stress field

group.name: gauge_volume
group.doc:
The gauge volume can be described with the following parameters: .. figure:: stress/gauge_volume.png :width: 70% :alt: Gauge volume parameters and coordinate system.
Gauge volume parameters and coordinate system.

field.name: a
field.doc: Length of the first diagonal.

field.name: b
field.doc: Length of the second diagonal normal to :ref:`x </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/gauge_volume/a-field>`.

field.name: c
field.doc: Height of the gauge volume.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: In the local coordinate system, the beam is aligned along the X-axis, and the Z-axis is oriented in the opposite direction of gravity. The origin is the center to the gauge volume.

group.doc: The last field typically depends on the first field of the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/SAMPLE_DESCRIPTION/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: The axis on which the sample position depends may be stored anywhere, but is normally stored in the NXtransformations group within the NXsample group.

group.doc: This is the recommended location for sample goniometer and other related axes.

group.name: FIT
group.doc: Zero or more groups to describe the data processing steps to obtain the content of this application definition.

field.name: raw_data_file
field.doc: The raw data file name(s) used during the data reduction process. This can be a list.

field.name: date
field.doc: Date when the raw data was reduced and the data in the *NXstress* file format generated.

field.name: program
field.doc: Software package used to perform data reduction including the version number or release date.

field.name: integration_type
field.doc: Describes how the data was integrated.

field.name: bins
field.doc: Describes the type of binning used during data reduction.

field.name: fit_type
field.doc: Describes how the fitting of the peaks was done. For example, single peak fit, multiple peak fit, Pawley refinement, Rietveld refinement, â€¦

field.name: fit_range
field.doc: Describes the data range used for peak fitting.

field.name: goodness_of_fit
field.doc: Type and value describing the goodness of fit. For example, Rw 0.23.

field.name: normalization
field.doc: Describes whether the data was normalized and if so , how. Examples of valid entries are: ``None``, ``time``, ``primary monitor``, ``detector``, â€¦

group.name: data_reduction_responsible
group.doc: Information about the person who performed the data reduction.

field.name: role
field.doc: Role of user responsible for this entry. Suggested roles are, for example, ``local contact``, ``beamline_scientist``, ``post_doc``,â€¦

group.name: DESCRIPTION
group.doc:
The note will contain information about how the data was processed or anything about the data provenance. The contents of the note can be anything that the processing code can understand, or a simple text.
The name will be numbered to allow for ordering of steps.

group.name: peak_parameters
group.doc: This group contains all diffraction peak fit parameters. This information is not required for stress and strain calculations.

field.name: title
field.doc: Diffraction peak profile.

field.name: area
field.doc: Diffraction peak area (not including the background) in *y_Unit* units.

field.name: area_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`area </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/area-field>`

field.name: center
field.doc: Diffraction peak position in *x_Unit* units.

field.name: center_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`center </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/center-field>`

field.name: height
field.doc: Diffraction peak height (not including the background) in *y_Unit* units.

field.name: height_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`height </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/height-field>`

field.name: fwhm
field.doc: Diffraction peak full width at half maximum in *x_Unit* units.

field.name: fwhm_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`fwhm </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/fwhm-field>`

field.name: fwhm_left
field.doc: Left-side FWHM for split profiles in *x_Unit* units.

field.name: fwhm_left_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`fwhm_left </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/fwhm_left-field>`

field.name: fwhm_right
field.doc: Right-side FWHM for split profiles in *x_Unit* units.

field.name: fwhm_right_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`fwhm_right </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/fwhm_right-field>`

field.name: form_factor
field.doc: - Voigt or Pseudo-Voigt: Lorentzian fraction - Pearson VII: decay parameter - Other profiles: not applicable

field.name: form_factor_errors
field.doc: Error value(s) asscociated with :ref:`form_factor </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters/form_factor-field>`

field.name: azimuth
field.doc: Angle that defines the position of the integrated sector in the diffraction cone for angular-dispersive diffraction or the position of the detector for energy-dispersive diffraction.

group.name: background_parameters
group.doc: This group contains all background fit parameters. This information is not required for stress and strain calculations.

field.name: title
field.doc:
Diffraction background profile. Required when background parameter fields are present. Some example values with equations are shown below:
- ``manual`` : No equations nor variables needed to describe this background. - ``linear`` : \ :math:`\small background= A0 + A1 \cdot x` - ``5-degree polynomial`` : \ :math:`\small background= A0 + A1 \cdot x + A2 \cdot \mathrm{x}^{2} + A3 \cdot \mathrm{x}^{3} + A4 \cdot \mathrm{x}^{4} + A5 \cdot \mathrm{x}^{5}` - ``shape function plus polynomial`` : A shape function is not a mathematical function, it contains a manual background obtained from a fit and a polynomial part. This allows to adapt and modify the fit for subsequent measurements in the same measurement campaign. The function describing it is the following: \ :math:`\small background= as + b \cdot SHAPE(x-o)` Where SHAPE is the name of the variable used to describe the background value at the position x. x can be e.g. the scattering angle \ :math:`2\theta` in degrees.

field.name: A
field.doc: Background parameter(s). For example a second-degree polynomial will have fields ``A0``, ``A1`` and ``A2``.

field.name: as
field.doc: Background parameter *constant* for SHAPE function.

field.name: as_errors
field.doc: Error associated with background parameter *constant* for SHAPE function.

field.name: b
field.doc: Background parameter *amplitude* for SHAPE function.

field.name: b_errors
field.doc: Error associated with background parameter *amplitude* for SHAPE function.

field.name: o
field.doc: Background parameter *offset* for SHAPE function.

field.name: o_errors
field.doc: Error associated with background parameter *offset* for SHAPE function.

field.name: background_area
field.doc: The background area in *y_Unit* units, integrated over a confidence interval around the center (*0.95* by default).

field.name: background_area_interval
field.doc: Confidence interval from which the background counts are integrated. For example *0.95* means that the background is integrated over the range in which the integrated peak area is 95% of the total peak area.

group.name: DIFFRACTOGRAM
group.doc: Diffractogram with fit results in :ref:`peak_parameters </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters-group>` and :ref:`background_parameters </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/background_parameters-group>`. This information is not required for stress and strain calculations.

attribute.name: axes
attribute.doc: List of the one to two axes field name(s) to be used by default. The axes are further described in the fields DAXIS and XAXIS.

field.name: DAXIS
field.doc: One or more fields that contain the values for the **n_D** dimension. For example the azimuthal positions of different energy-dispersive detectors or the average azimuth of different azimuthal sections on an area detector.

field.name: XAXIS
field.doc: One or more fields that contain the values for the **n_X** dimension in *x_Unit* units. For example: MCA channels, scattering angle \ :math:`2\theta` in degrees, scattering vector length q in \ :math:`\mathrm{nm}^{-1}`, ...

attribute.name: signal
attribute.doc: Default field name to be plotted.

attribute.name: auxiliary_signals
attribute.doc: List of additional field names to be plotted. This could be e.g. fit, background, residuals, â€¦

field.name: diffractogram
field.doc: Diffractogram counts in *y_Unit* units (default signal)

field.name: diffractogram_errors
field.doc: Diffractogram counts error in *y_Unit* units (default signal)

field.name: fit
field.doc: Diffractogram fit counts (auxiliary signal).

field.name: fit_errors
field.doc: Diffractogram fit counts error (auxiliary signal).

field.name: background
field.doc: In case the diffraction background was manually determined. Diffractogram background counts (auxiliary signal).

field.name: residuals
field.doc: Difference between diffractogram and fit (auxiliary signal).

group.name: NOTES
group.doc: User description of the data acquisitions. A description of data analysis goes in the :ref:`fit descriptions </NXstress/ENTRY/FIT/DESCRIPTION-group>`.

group.name: peaks
group.doc: This group contains all diffraction peak parameters that could be needed for stress and strain calculations. These parameters are derived from :ref:`peak_parameters </NXstress/ENTRY/fit/peak_parameters-group>` and additional metadata.

field.name: h
field.doc: First Miller index.

field.name: k
field.doc: Second Miller index.

field.name: l
field.doc: Third Miller index.

field.name: lattice
field.doc: Crystal lattice systems (*cubic*, *hexagonal*, ...)

field.name: space_group
field.doc: Crystallographic space group :math:`(Fm\bar{3}m, Im\bar{3}m, ...)`

field.name: phase_name
field.doc: Name of the crystallographic phase (hematite, goethite, \ :math:`\alpha`-Al\ :sub:`2`\ O\ :sub:`3`\ , ...).

field.name: qx
field.doc: First component of the *normalized* scattering vector *Q* in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: qy
field.doc: Second component of the *normalized* scattering vector *Q* in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: qz
field.doc: Third component of the *normalized* scattering vector *Q* in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: center
field.doc: Diffraction peak position in *c_Unit* units.

field.name: center_errors
field.doc: Uncentrainties on :ref:`center </NXstress/ENTRY/peaks/center-field>` in *c_Unit* units.

field.name: center_type
field.doc:
The space in which :ref:`center </NXstress/ENTRY/peaks/center-field>` is defined. It defines the *c_Unit* as follows
- if *center_type="two-theta"* then *c_Unit* must have the angle unit *degrees* - if *center_type="energy"* then *c_Unit* must have the unit *keV* - if *center_type="momentum-transfer"* then *c_Unit* must have the unit \ :math:`Ã…^{-1}` - if *center_type="d-spacing"* then *c_Unit* must have the unit \ :math:`Ã…` - if *center_type="channel"* then *c_Unit* must be *dimensioness* - if *center_type="time-of-flight"* then *c_Unit* must have the unit \ :math:`\mu\mathrm{s}`

field.name: sx
field.doc: First component of the sample position in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: sy
field.doc: First component of the sample position in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.

field.name: sz
field.doc: First component of the sample position in the sample reference frame. The sample reference frame is defined by the :ref:`sample transformations </NXstress/ENTRY/sample_description/TRANSFORMATIONS-group>`.
